title: FA Cup clash with Leeds won't rattle Cambridge captain and former care-home worker Leon Legge
text:
Whatever Monday night has in store, it won't be as hard as the 24-hour shift Legge once worked (Photo: Getty) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Cambridge captain Leon Legge has no fears of a tough shift against in-form Leeds in the FA Cup after working in a care home before turning pro. 
The former Gillingham defender, who suffers from epilepsy and is an ambassador for an epilepsy charity, helped adults with learning difficulties before joining Brentford when he was 24. 
“I fell into it after doing sports science at college and it was a good thing to give something back,” said Legge, now 31, whose League Two side host Garry Monk's Championship promotion chasers on Monday night. 
“I was there for two years. You had your good days and your bad days, like any other job. You see what some people go through. It can be tough. They were long days – 12-hour shifts. One day, someone couldn’t come in and I did 24 hours. Leeds are pushing for promotion after being out of the top flight since 2004 (Photo: Action Images) 
“When I was in non-League with Tonbridge I was sometimes going straight to play a match on a Tuesday night after a 12-hour shift. It was hard, but it didn’t bother me because I love the game. 
“I didn’t want to leave, but the opportunity to play ­football professionally was one I had to take. I had to say my goodbyes to my old work and that was it. 
“There was one lad there who had epilepsy and I could relate to how he was feeling, which made my job easier. Going from that to what I’m doing, it gives you that sense of gratitude. Cup ties like these are the sort of things you tell your grandchildren about.” 
Legge still takes daily medication, but has proved epilepsy is no barrier to success in sport. Boss Derry says he has a plan to deal with in-form Leeds (Photo: Getty) 
“It’s something I’ve lived with for the last 15 years, but it has never got in my way,” he said. “More sportsmen and women have come out and said they have epilepsy. They go through the same journey as me – Greg Rutherford, James Cracknell, Matt Crooks of Rangers.” 
After failing to win their first eight League Two games and sitting bottom of the entire Football League, Shaun Derry’s side have won seven out of eight to now sit a point off the play-offs. 
The visitors are in good nick too, but former Leeds player Derry said: “There is a game plan and we want to do ourselves justice.” 
* STUART DALLAS reckons Leeds’ strong recent form will count for nothing against Cambridge. 
The Whites’ winger has seen his side go unbeaten in their last five game to raise the prospect of promotion back to the Premier League. But the Northern Ireland international warned that a place in the fourth round will have to be earned. Dallas (right) and co are on a fine run of form — but so are Cambridge (Photo: Action Images) 
Dallas said: “Cambridge have been on a good run in their league, they are going to be a strong physical team like all League Two teams. 
"We have to respect Cambridge, it is going to be a tough place to go, it is a small ground and it will be a good atmosphere. It is something the boys are looking forward to.” 
Boss Monk will make changes with one eye on Friday night's fifth vs seventh game at home to Derby, but Dallas does not think there will be any complacency. 
He added: “I always want to play as much as I can. It is a very competitive squad, you need to be on top of your game at all times.” Like us on Facebook
